Replacement Array is an array of elements.

Format String contains conversion specifier %s, followed by optional index specifier [1], followed by optional length specifier :3.

Format String: %s[1]:3

%s is conversion specifier - mark the starting of conversion string
[1] is index specifier - corresponding index of Replacement Array
:3 is length specifier - number of characters to be taken from string
The replacement works as follows:

Example:
Replacement Array: Smart site India comparison Best

Format String: %sprix is the %s[4] online %s[3]:6 shopping %s:9 in %s

Output: Smartprix is the Best online compar shopping site in India.

If no index specifier is present with conversion specifier %s, Index 0, 1, 2, 3... are assigned to all in sequence from left to right.
In above example %sprix is %s[0]prix; %s:9 is %s[1]:9 and so on.
The specifier string is replaced by element of Replacement Array denoted by index specifier. If no element is found the specifier is not replaced.
In above example %s[4] is replaced by element at 4th index of the Replacement Array "Best". %sprix is replaced by Smartprix and so on.
%s[3]:6 is replaced by 'first 6 characters' of the element at 3rd index of the Replacement Array, i.e., "compar".
If the 'length specifier' is not present or is greater than length of the element then use whole string.
%s:9 is replaced by site, %s[4] is replaced by Best.
For any error case, specifier is not replaced.
Input:
There will be 2 lines in the input.

1st line contains space separated elements of Replacement Array
2nd line is Format String
Output:
Formatted String
Example 1:
Input:

Smart site India comparison Best
%sprix is the %s[4] online %s[3]:6 shopping %s:9 in %s.
Output:

Smartprix is the Best online compar shopping site in India.
Example 2:
Input:

India boom startup up hub
%s %s[is] a %sing %s:5%s:5 %s[4]. And %s[6] are:4 of %s[-1].
Output:

India %s[is] a booming startup hub. And %s[6] are:4 of %s[-1].

why does my first one still work? I'm assuming it's because since I'm finding the halfway point, and Ruby allows you to search negative indexes, that it amounts to the same thing.

```
def my_search(arr, key, min, max)
	half = (max-min)/2
	return "Found #{key} at #{half}!" if arr[half] == key
	if key > arr[half]
		my_search(arr, key, half, max)
	elsif key < arr[half]
		my_search(arr, key, min, half)
	end
end
```

thanks! I actually came here with a Ruby question. not so much a problem with my code, but how it works. I'm starting to get into recursion and sorting algorithms. I had this for a binary search:
```
def my_search(arr, key, min, max)
    half = (min-max)/2
    return "Found #{arr[half]} at #{half}!" if arr[half] == key
    if key > arr[half]
        my_search(arr, key, half, max)
    elsif key < arr[half]
        my_search(arr, key, min, half)
    end
end
```

```
class Array
  def mmp
    out = []
    self.each { |e| out << yield(e)}
    out
  end

  def mmp2(&my_proc)
    out = []
    self.each { |e| out << my_proc.call(e)}
    out
  end
end

a = [1, 2, 3, 4]
a.mmp  { |x| x + 2 } # => [3, 4, 5, 6]
a.mmp2 { |x| x + 2 } # => [3, 4, 5, 6]

```
def ipsBetween(start, ending)
  start_arr = start.split(".").map{|x| x.to_i}
  end_arr = ending.split(".").map{|x| x.to_i}
  values = [1703936,65536,256,1]
  start_sum = 0
  end_sum = 0
  start_arr.each_with_index do |num, index|
    start_sum += values[index] * num
  end
  
  end_arr.each_with_index do |num, index|
    end_sum += values[index] * num
  end
  (end_sum - start_sum).abs
end
```

```
def bubble_sort_by(array) 
  counter = array.size - 1

  while counter > 0
    1.upto(counter) do |number|
      if yield(array[number - 1], array[number]) < 0
        array[number - 1], array[number] = array[number], array[number - 1]
      end
    end
    counter -= 1
  end

  return array
end
```

    arr
end

```
def bubble_sort(arr)
    while arr != arr.sort
        arr.each_with_index do |val, index|
            if val != arr[-1] and val > arr[index + 1]
                arr[index], arr[index + 1] = arr[index + 1], arr[index]
            end
        end
    end
    return arr
end

```
def caesar_cipher(str, difference)
	str.length.times do |i|
		if str[i].ord >= 97 and str[i].ord <= 122
			if str[i].ord + difference > 122
				str[i] = (97 + (str[i].ord + difference - 123)).chr
			else
				str[i] = (str[i].ord + difference).chr
			end
		elsif str[i].ord >= 65 and str[i].ord <= 90
			if str[i].ord + difference > 90
				str[i] = (65 + (str[i].ord + difference - 91)).chr
			else
				str[i] = (str[i].ord + difference).chr
			end
		end
	end

	str
end

caesar_cipher("What a string!", 5)
```

nevermind, i got it to work! i also added functionality to link to the related articles and i made it so that only tags with an article show up, so if you delete all of the articles of a specific tag it will no longer show in the list. i know it's not much to you experts, but i'm really proud of it!

```
class Article < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :comments
  has_many :taggings
  has_many :tags, through: :taggings
  
  def tag_list
    self.tags.collect do |tag|
      tag.name
    end.join(", ")
  end
  
  def tag_list=(tags_string)
    tag_names = tags_string.split(", ").collect{|s| s.strip.downcase}.uniq
    new_or_found_tags = tag_names.collect { |name| Tag.find_or_create_by(name: name) }
    self.tags = new_or_found_tags
  end
end

```

Hello! I am Ruby on Rails Backed developer since May, 2011.

@/all we need some help with picking Ruby challenge topics for in-browser practice. What all would you recommend? We have room for, like, 20 challenges for now.

Before you go ahead and propose, here are some things you **cannot do** within the in-browser challenges:
- import a gem that's not part of core Ruby, and  probably needs a `gem install` or `bundle install`.
- code spread over multiple files.
- connect to a DB or start a server etc.

I am thinking we pick them in an order that encourages reading Ruby documentation and understanding what needs to be done, or which method would work better for the usecase at hand. We also intend to encourage TDD.

Also the challenges should encourage best practices.

## :point_right: [how to create a campsite for your city [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/how-to-create-a-campsite-for-your-city) If you didn't see your city on [our list of Campsites](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/freecodecamp/wiki/List-of-Free-Code-Camp-city-based-Campsites), you should create your own Facebook group.
We like keeping things as local as possible, so please create groups only for cities, or even smaller areas. Please, do not create campsites for a whole State/province/department/county/etc. as they will not be added to the list. ------
Now, to the fun part! It's easy, just follow these steps: - Sign in to Facebook. - Click the down arrow in the upper right corner of the screen, then choose "Create Group" from the options. ![A screenshot of Facebook showing the drop down menu that appears when you click the down arrow, with an arrow pointing to the "Create Group" option](https://www.evernote.com/shard/s116/sh/d01bb2bc-6260-4987-bedf-b2ce4c31972f/3eecbcff3109036cf90b69589360f407/deep/0/Facebook.png)
- Set the group name as "Free Code Camp" plus the proper name of your city.
Avoid using slang terms such as "Philly" for "Philadelphia". If your city is not the biggest city that uses its name, also include the state or province. For example, the Free Code Camp group in Paris, France should be called "Free Code Camp Paris". The Free Code Camp group in Paris, Texas should be called "Free Code Camp Paris, Texas".
If you are in North America, we suggest you add the initials of your state/province here. - Set your group to public. - You'll need to add at least one person in order to create the group. Why not add [Justin](https://www.facebook.com/FCC.campsiteCounsellor)!? Furthermore, if you make him an admin, he'll be able to assist you in managing your members and events. ![A screenshot of the Facebook group creation modal saying that your group name should be Free Code Camp plus your city name, that your group should be public, and that you need to invite at least one Facebook friend.](https://www.evernote.com/shard/s116/sh/4ed3197c-db1b-4103-a040-b42482ad232a/6c34948ebe12c57f0b7a54d7b2222ab3/deep/0/Facebook.png) :pencil: [read more about how to create a campsite for your city on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/how-to-create-a-campsite-for-your-city)

ruby doesnt need to use  paranthese iun a method call most the time.

```
def AND(val1, val2)
  if val1 == val2 
    return true
  else
    return false
  end
end
 
def OR(val1, val2)
  if val1 == true || val2 == true
    return true
  else
    return false
  end
end
 
def NOR(val1, val2)
  if val1 != true && val2 != true
    return true
  else
    return false
  end
end
 
def XOR(val1, val2)
  if val1 != val2
    return true
  else
    return false
  end
end
 
def NAND(val1, val2)
  if val1 != val2
    return true
  else
    return false
  end
end
 
def XAND(val1, val2)
  if val2 != val1
    return false
  else
    return true
  end
end
 
def NOT(val)
  if val == true
    return false
  else
    return true
  end
end
```
thats the methods I've made for use with logic loops such as flip flops and latches

require 'book'

        end

    end
  end
end

this solved it, but I know it's not effecient

```
def translate(string)
	vowels = "aeiou"
	string = string.split
	string.each do |word|
		ind = string.index(word)
		if(vowels.include?(word[0]))
			word += "ay"
			string[ind] = word

		elsif(word[0..1] == "qu")
			to_move = word.slice!(0..1)
			word += to_move + "ay"
			string[ind] = word

		elsif(word[1..2] == "qu")
			to_move = word.slice!(0..2)
			word += to_move + "ay"
			string[ind] = word

		else
			while(not vowels.include?(word[0]))
				to_move = word.slice!(0)
				word += to_move
			end
			word = word + "ay"
			string[ind] = word
		end
	end

	return string.join(" ")

end
```

	string = string.split
	string.each do |word|
		if(vowels.include?(word[0]))
			word += "ay"

		else
			while(not vowels.include?(word[0]))
				to_move = word.slice!(0)
				word += to_move
			end
		end
	end

	return string

end
```

https://www.ruby-forum.com/topic/168081

@rocksynth 
> > What advantage or difference has a procedure (Proc) over a method?

A method is executed as a direct result of sending a message to an
object:

   "hello".upcase   # the message is 'upcase', which resolves to a
        # method name

A Proc object gets called by sending *it* a message:

   pr = Proc.new { puts "I am a Proc!" }
   pr.call   # prints: I am a Proc!

Every method is defined inside a class or module, and executing the
method depends on having an object that will be able to find the
method. Procs, however, are handed around like other objects: a Proc
you create in one context can be called in another. Procs do not
belong to classes or modules.

There's more, but those are some basic differences.

def first_square_numbers(number_of_squares)

can you use a conditional to check if there already is a subscription?

So in rails if you've got a has_one association (let's say a User has_one Subscription)

If that user already has a subscription and visits /users/1/subscriptions/new

It'll hit the subscriptions_controller

```
def new
  user = User.find(params[:user_id)])
  @subscription = user.build_subscription
end
```

No harm no foul right? But just the act of visiting that link will destroy the the user's old subscription. Building the tentative record will destroy the old one

On a GET request nonetheless!

Anyway I thought that was kinda ridiculous.. I never knew build was so destructive

This was a real example, but albeit complicated. Say, you are creating a wordpress template for portfolio site. But a template is meant to be used by more than one people - they would customize it based on what color they like, what their names are etc.

Now, they don't know Wordpress, otherwise they won't be using your template. But you want them to be able to customize and personalize it.

So, you tell them to open a YAML file and edit personal info; like name, contact, address etc. there. Your code should be set up in away to read from the YAML file and store those in some variables when you are running the application.

@acaisia yeah. Let me give you an example. This discussion is valid for most of the repos on GitHub, but let's take our [main repo](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp).

It has a [.travis.yml](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/blob/staging/.travis.yml) file. 

When someone submits their code on GitHub to this repo, there are some automated checks run in a remote machine. It downloads the repo, adds your code, and runs what you tell it to run.

This system is called continuous integration, and it's a very standard thing in software development - when someone submits code to be merged in a large codebase, there should be some process that would take your codebase, add your code, and run _pre-specified_ tests on it. 

GitHub uses [Travis](https://travis-ci.org/) as the service for this. Now, most GitHub repos have this set-up with travis - if someone submits new code, it would run some stuff. So, most repos have this travis.yml file.

The file is in YAML format, and has .yml extension. YAML is a platform independent file format. It's kinda like JSON. JSON is a standard focused on trasmission; while YAML is meant for easy reading and quick loading in memory.

Repo to Repo, the tests vary. Your repo could be in Ruby, mine could be in Node and Python. Also, the tests to run would vary.

So, `.travis.yml` for every repo has this info - it will tell Travis CI what the repo code is based on, where the test files are located etc.

You can read the travis.yml of a few repos and understand the info contained in it. Also check the executions on travis CI to see how it runs the build and tests one by one.

```
words = ["here", "are", "some", "words"]

	else
		word.upcase
	end
end

puts words

    	else

    	end

@PJonestown I'm pretty sure for loops in ruby and array[array.length -1] works the same way as JS. for loop in ruby can also be written as:
```for i in array[0]..array.length```
   ```puts "Value of local variable is #{i}"```
```end```
 each,map,etc are enumerators which makes looping easy for developers and is actually better. Ruby was specifically built for developer's happiness. You can do it with ruby magic and also without ruby magic :) thats the great thing about ruby.
Though I will not say it is better to learn one first versus another. JS is obviously extremely useful and important. I wish I had more of a foundation in it the more Rails stuff I did.
enumeration > loops

Just another example, from my own personal experience, if you wanted to access the last element of an array in ruby you'd do
```
array[-1]
```

I just thought this was a logical syntax and left it at that. It was only after I learned the js way

```
array[array.length - 1]
```

that I actually understood where the syntax came from and knew exactly how it worked.

@twhite96 I prefer the ruby way too :) but the issue here isn't about which is more logical. The js version of iterating through an array clearly shows how the iterator works and how each array element is accessed. The ruby version doesn't expose any inner workings
Hello! RUBY <3
Actually that Ruby syntax is more logical to me than a js for loop
There's a lot of magic going on. So much so that my algorithm practice for interviews is always in js to make it a bit more difficult. Worst of all, ruby will spoil you, it did at least for me :)

@johnburkhard I learned ruby and rails first. I honestly don't think it matters, but if I had to choose I'd suspect that learning js would actually be  better because there's a lot less magic. For example, if you wanted to print out each element in an array in js you'd do 
```
for(i=0; i<array.length; i++) {
  console.log(array[i])
}
```
You get a clear idea of what this does and how it works, ruby however hides a lot of the internals for developer happiness

```
array.each do |n|
  puts n
end
```
So does anyone else think that learning ruby might be a better idea then focusing 100% on JS first?
